history.content:
Generally speaking behavioral questions are more difficult to prepare for than coding questions. The best way is to be really familiar with your past experience. You should go through all the things you have done for school, extra curricular activities, and if you have it, your work experience. You should think about times that you have demonstrated creativity, problem solving ability, dedication, the ability to work in a team, the ability to lead a team, or anything you are particularly proud of. It may be difficult to think of examples of some of these but it is likely you can think of examples of most if not all. 

I think it is likely you have worked in a team setting but if you really can't think of a time that you have worked in a team setting I suggest you join a club that will let you work with a team. Regardless, you should do this for more reasons than just the machiavellian purpose of having things to talk about in an interview. Most large, important things done in the world are done in teams (which is why companies want to know you can work in them) so learning to work effectively with others is important. Additionally, you can learn from the people you work with and working with people can be fun. 

Don't ever say you don't have experience with a situation posed in a behavioral interview (unless it's something ridiculous, working in a team or using technology are both very reasonable). There is a reason they want to hear what you have to say and telling them nothing will invariable work against you. Even if you can't think of a perfect experiential fit say something that fits as close as possible. Behavioral questions are more about demonstrating thoughtfulness and positive personal attributes rather than listing experience (they have your resume which is already that) so there is a lot of latitude in what a "good answer" looks like.

Don't just apply to startups, apply to all the places you think you would like to work at and would be a good fit at, they will decide if they want to hire you. You never know what they will do, most apps are short anyways.

children.subject: I've mentioned things from all sorts of activities. It matters more that you have that experience, because it can be applied anywhere. If you have great leadership experience as captain of a soccer team, that experience doesn't leave you just because you're doing computer science. While there may be differences in the personality types you interact with, its more about the fact that you have that experience, because the underlying experience is what matters, not where you got it.

Thank you! I appreciate the advice. Also, if a question asks about something without mentioning a setting (ex. describe a time you had to fix a problem involving your team), is it strictly limited to computer science or could I mention a sports team from MS/HS or something? Should all experiences be fairly recent, too?

history.content:
For context, I’m a sophomore declared CS major that’s taking 170 and 186 this semester.

I’m having a hard time preparing for interviews involving behavioral questions. There are so many different behavioral questions that can be asked, so how can I be able to, in an interview, come up with an answer to a question I hadn’t seen before? I’m sure there are some questions I could BS, but I’ve seen some questions online that if I was asked in an interview I would have no idea how to answer. For example, the question “Describe a time when you used technology to solve a problem in an academic, work, team, or volunteer setting” would destroy me lol.

Also, really my only time that I have worked on a team project was the CS 61B Database project in Sp ‘17, and it was just a 2 person project. Would I be penalized for this in an interview (eg if I was asked a question about a team project and I said “sorry, I’ve never experienced that situation because I have little experience doing a CS project with a team)? Or would you guys just recommend that due to this I should apply to mostly startups, which aren’t as concerned about experience?

Thanks!
history.subject: Interview Advice
